word.title: Absolute Direction
word.description: A compass direction (N,S,E,W).

word.title: Absolute Location
word.description: The exact location of a place or item using latitude and longitude.
word.example: 33°45'N 84°23'W are the coordinates of Atlanta, Georgia.

word.title: Accessibility
word.description: The ease to be able to travel from one place to another.
word.example: It is easy to drive to Kroger, but difficult to drive to Canada.
Driving over mountains takes longer than flat land.

word.title: Acculturation
word.description: Adapting certain customs that will benefit them.
word.example: A English family that migrated to the US will most likely adapt to the culture in their new home.
A native Russian family will most likely not adapt to the culture of the countries around Russia.

word.title: Activity Space
word.description: Space used for a specific activity or industry.
word.example: Driving from to work and back.
Riding the bus to school and back.

word.title: Adaptive Strategies
word.description: The way a culture uses its physical environment.
word.example: Many cultures farm on a percentage of their land.
some cultures set aside a certain amount of their land to be used for religious purposes.

word.title: Age Distribution
word.description: In a population pyramid, there are two back-to-back bar graphs, one male and one female. These graphs show the gender ration in an area.
word.example: In 2004, the US male population of 80+ was about 2% of the entire population.
In 2004, the Pakistani female population of 0-4 was about 15% of the entire population.

word.title: Agglomeration
word.description: A tight group or cluster; concentrating together to share the same resources.

word.title: Animism
word.description: A belief where inanimate objects are worshipped because they are believed to have spirits inside of them.

word.title: Architectural Form
word.description: The look of architecture based on the popular culture, environment, and available materials in the area.
word.example: Hindi temples usually have tall towers that are carved.
Stucco-style houses are common in the Southwestern United States.

word.title: Arithmetic Population Density
word.description: The total population divided by the total land mass.
word.example: The arithmetic population density in Japan is 875 people per square mile.
The arithmetic population density in Bangladesh is 2542 people per sq. mile.

word.title: Assimilation
word.description: Losing your culture to a more dominant culture.
word.example: Many Native groups have lost their culture to the main culture of the country they live in.
Many ethnic groups have been forced to give up their culture.

word.title: Authenticity
word.description: Looking past stereotypes and looking at the real culture.
word.example: It was the Oriental who created the noodle, not the Italians.
Not all Southerners drink Sweet Tea.

word.title: Barriadas
word.description: a type of "squatter settlement", ghetto, or shantytown that is on the outskirts of an urban area.

word.title: Barrio
word.description: ethnic neighborhood in Latin America cities.
word.example: usually the poorer areas in the city
usually the zone of peripheral squatter settlements according to the Latin American city model

word.title: Bid-rent Theory
word.description: a theory about real-estate prices as properties move further away from CBDs.
word.example: There aren't retail shops in residential areas.
Rent for an office building is much more expensive in a shopping center than a residential area.

word.title: Blockbusting
word.description: A real-estate practice to influence white people to sell their property by suggesting that the surrounding area is declining in value, usually by implying a change in racial mix; a rapid change in racial composition.
word.example: In the Great Migration, many black people migrated to the North to work in cities, which lowered real estate prices and frightened white people.
Many Chicago real estate companies had been accused of block-busting in 1962.

word.title: Boundary
word.description: The division between two states; this is not only described by the invisible, 2D lines represented on a map, but even the ground below and the airspace above a state (a boundary is a vertical plane, not just a two-dimensional line).

word.title: Boundary Process
word.description: The process of creating a boundary includes four steps: definition, often a treaty-like document that records the actual points of the landscape or describes the absolute location of the boundaries; delimitation, the actual drawing of the state's boundaries on a map by cartographers; demarcation, the physical bordering of the state with steel posts, concrete pillars, fences, or walls (often impractical or too expensive); and administration, which is how states regulate and maintain these boundaries.

word.title: Buddhism
word.description: One of the world's major universalizing religion.

word.title: Built Environment
word.description: the man made imprint on a landscape.
word.example: A McDonald's restaurant on a street corner.

word.title: Capitalism
word.description: Rather than the government, in capitalism the people, corporations, or states (with the goal of earning a profit) exchange produced goods with the world market. Producers can commodify products and take advantage of the world labor supply to maximize profit. The capitalistic market began in the 15th century and spread through European colonialism, finally including the entire world by the 20th century.

word.title: Carrying Capacity
word.description: the amount of people a certain area can support.
word.example: Every country has a carrying capacity.
If the population grows more than the carrying capacity, there won't be enough food, water, and shelter to support the entire population.

word.title: Central Business District
word.description: the concentrated central area in a city that is the hearth of government, retail, transportation, and business.

word.title: Census tract
word.description: A statistical subdivision that is smaller than a county, which is used to count the population.
word.example: California is completely covered with census tracts.
Metropolitan areas use census tracts to hold a population count.

word.title: Centrality
word.description: to be centered; equal distance from all objects; a strong central urban center, with the power to attract producers and consumers.
word.example: The commons area of a high school is usually in the central area of the school.
Times square in New York is a CBD.

word.title: Centralization
word.description: the act of businesses and governments moving to a central location.
word.example: Shrines and temples in the center of the city in Mesopotamia.
Businesses have flocked to the focal point of Suwanee, Suwanee park

word.title: Centralized Pattern
word.description: The dispersal of population is agglomerated, or clumped together.
word.example: The guests gathered in a centralized pattern on the dance floor.

word.title: Central-place theory
word.description: a theory that explains why urban systems are placed where they are; explores the place, size, and population.

word.title: Centrifugal
word.description: A force that divides a state or nation, described by the political geographer Richard Hartshorne. Examples range from internal religious conflicts to political, ethnic, or economic differences.

word.title: Centripetal
word.description: A force that unify the people within a common state or nation, described by the political geographer Richard Hartshorne. These could be as simple as a national culture and common faith or even as complex as the unification during a war.

word.title: Chain Migration
word.description: one member of a family migrates to a new country and the rest of the family follows shortly after.
word.example: A father from Russia migrates to the US. Three years later, the rest of his family moves from Russia to the US.
A brother from Mexico migrates to the US. He sends money to his family in Mexico every month. Five years later, the rest of his family moves to the US.

word.title: Christaller, Walter
word.description: A German geographer who created the Central-place theory; researched urban systems.
word.example: Central place theory: New York City

word.title: Christianity
word.description: a monotheistic religion based on the teachings of Jesus Christ.

word.title: City
word.description: a conglomeration or tight cluster of people and buildings that group together to form a universal center of politics, culture, and economics.

word.title: Cityscape
word.description: an urban landscape; how a city looks, which includes the building architecture, roads, landmarks, etc.

word.title: Clustered/ Agglomerrated Settlement
word.description: Houses are clumped into one area.
word.example: Location of homes in New York City.

word.title: Cohort
word.description: population in a category on an age-sex population pyramid.
word.example: The 45-49 age group on a population pyramid
The 0-4 age group on a population pyramid

word.title: Colonialism
word.description: Although often referring to the European colonization during the 16th century (because of its magnitude and impact), colonialism is a general term that describes the rule of a country over an alien, separate people and place. The established settlements are imposed political and economic control by the autonomous power, often resulting in unequal economic and cultural relations.

word.title: Colonial city
word.description: cities that were founded and created by colonial powers long ago.

word.title: Commercialization
word.description: exploiting a type of product to make a profit; introducing an item into the market; taking advantage of a situation to make money; using a city to attract tourists and money.
word.example: Christmas has become more about buying presents, decorations, dinner supplies, etc. than it has about the actual religious celebration.
Cities like New York City, Los Angeles, Paris, etc. that bring in exponential amounts of tourists.

word.title: Commodification
word.description: A process used by producers to maximize profit involving selling, buying, and exchanging priced products. "Companies create new products, generate new twists on old products, and create demand for the products through marketing (De Blij et al., 2007, p.232)." An example is the 20th century fad for pet rocks or the newly marketed bottled water.

word.title: Commuter zone
word.description: a zone in the concentric zone model.

word.title: Concentric-Zone Model
word.description: a model that shows the structure of an American city that exhibits centrality that suggests a central district or zone, that is surrounded by 5 outer-rings.

word.title: Conference of Berlin (1884)
word.description: During the second wave of colonialism during the late 1800s, the major colonizers (Including Britain, France, the Netherlands, Belgium, Germany, and Italy) met in 1884 for the Berlin Conference. These colonizing parties met and divided up the map of Africa, deciding on the various colonies. Motives ranged from economic benefit to spreading Christianity.

word.title: Confucianism
word.description: a system developed in China based on moral, political, social, and political thoughts.

word.title: Connectivity
word.description: The linkage of one location to others.
word.example: A trail in the backyard to go to another house.

word.title: Contagious Diffusion
word.description: a character rapidly diffused through a population.

word.title: Core/periphery Model
word.description: The world economy is a three-tier structure: the core, the periphery, and semi-periphery. Core processes incorporate higher levels of education and include higher wages and more technology. There processes develop more wealth in the global economy. On the contrary, periphery processes include the lower levels of education and incorporate lower salaries and less technology. Semi-peripheries, as you can imagine, are simply a buffer between the two extremes of core and periphery. This process generally includes the exploitation of the periphery by the core. Although these are processes, they occur in places and are sometimes assigned to states. For example, the US and Canada are core states while Chile and Iraq are periphery.

word.title: Counterurbanization
word.description: people moving against the trend of rural to urban and moving from urban areas to rural ones.

word.title: Creole
word.description: a pidgin language that turned into the native language of a group of people.

word.title: Crude Birth Rate
word.description: the number of live births every year per 1,000 people in a population.
word.example: the CBR of the US is 15 live births per 1,000 people.
the CBR of Brazil is 20 live births per 1,000 people

word.title: Crude Death Rate
word.description: the number of deaths every year per 1,000 people in a population.
word.example: the CBR of the US is 12

word.title: Cultural Adaption
word.description: the change of a culture due to the presence of new cultures in the area.
word.example: Chinese food has become a part of the American culture
Spanish has become an increasingly popular language in the US due to the large amount of Spanish immigrants.

word.title: Cultural Core/Periphery Pattern
word.description: the core provides the main economic power and the peripheral or outer regions provide less economic power.
word.example: Atlanta is the core and the suburbs are the outer regions
Washington, D.C. is the core and surrounding cities are the periphery

word.title: Cultural Ecology
word.description: geographic study of the multiple interactions of human-environmental relationships.
word.example: humans planting new trees to make up for the trees that are cut down

word.title: Cultural Identity
word.description: belonging to a cultural group.
word.example: Chinese people are part of the Chinese culture
There is not a standard culture in America, there are many cultural groups

word.title: Cultural Landscape
word.description: the presence of human activity on a certain landscape.

word.title: Cultural Realm
word.description: a region where a culture prevails.

word.title: Cultural Shatter Belt
word.description: a politically unstable region in which many cultures live and there is conflict between them.

word.title: Culture
word.description: the knowledge, beliefs, behaviors, traditions, and social forms of a group of people.

word.title: Culture Region
word.description: a region where there is a common culture.

word.title: Cyclic Movement
word.description: a short term journey that begins at home and ends at home.
word.example: a week long trip to Florida and the coming back home

word.title: Decentralization
word.description: When cities are moving further away from the center, the CBDs are no longer a gravitational focus of the city.

word.title: Deindustrialization
word.description: the movement of industrial jobs and manufacturing to areas where labor isn't as cheap, therefore leaving behind a high service economy with a large proportion of unemployment.

word.title: Demographic Equation
word.description: a formula that calculates a population's change.
word.example: subtract CDR from CBR and add or subtract net migration.
if the CBR and CDR are =, and immigration and emigration rates are =, it is zero.

word.title: Demographic Momentum
word.description: the tendency for a growing population to continue growing after a fertility decline because of the population's young age distribution.
word.example: growth even with a restrictive population policy.
can happen after a sudden increase in the population, like the Baby Boom.

word.title: Demographic Region
word.description: what stage on the Demographic Transition Model a certain region is in.
word.example: Most of sub-Saharan Africa is in Stage 2 of the DTM.
two-thirds of North America are in Stage 4 of the DTM.

word.title: Demographic Transition Model
word.description: a representation of what stage of growth a country is in.
word.example: there are no countries currently in stage 1.

word.title: Dependency Ratio
word.description: the ratio of the number of people either too young or to old to work to the number of people that can work and support those who can't work.
word.example: higher in countries with more younger and older people.
Japan has a large population of people who cannot work, mostly elderly people.

word.title: Devolution
word.description: The change in political power in a state, from a more centralized unitary system to a more federal system. This can be permanently written in a reconstructed constitution (as in Spain) or temporary without the alteration of a constitution (as in the United Kingdom).

word.title: Dialect
word.description: a variation of a language.

word.title: Diffusion
word.description: the spread of ideas and innovations.

word.title: Diffusion of Fertility Control
word.description: when fertility control spreads to the different areas of the world.
word.example: the high rate of AIDS in Africa shows there is not much fertility control in Africa.

word.title: Disease Diffusion
word.description: how a disease spreads from place to place.
word.example: The Bubonic plaque was spread by fleas that were on rats that were on ships.
Swine flu was brought to the US by a group of US citizens after a trip.

word.title: Dispersion/ Scattered Settlement
word.description: Houses are far from one another.

word.title: Distance Decay
word.description: when the communication between two separate groups stops because of the distance between them.
word.example: time-space compression almost eliminates distance decay.

word.title: Distribution
word.description: The dispersal of a product or service across an area.

word.title: Doubling Time
word.description: the total time it takes for a certain population to double in size and number.
word.example: the doubling time for the world population 2,000 years ago was 1,600 years.
the world's doubling times is currently 51 years.

word.title: Dowry Death
word.description: In arranged marriages in India, the bride's father is responsible for paying a dowry(a price paid to the father of the groom). If he refuses, the bride can be killed.
word.example: there can be disputes over the price of the dowry.

word.title: Early cities
word.description: created in the first urban revolution, about 3500 to 1500 years ago, origin of agriculture and language.

word.title: Economic base
word.description: (basic/nonbasic)Community's collection of basic industry.

word.title: Ecumene
word.description: the proportion of Earth's surface that is occupied by permanent human settlements.
word.example: only about 40% of Earth's surface is inhabited by human settlements.
the majority of Canada's population is located near the Canadian-US border.

word.title: Edge city
word.description: an area on the outskirts of a CBD where urbanization is starting to shift towards; high office/retail space, few residential areas, and modern buildings are characteristics of edge cities.

word.title: Emerging cities
word.description: Cities with a low population, but alarmingly high growth rate.

word.title: Enclave
word.description: a territory in which its boundaries are inside the boundaries of another territory.

word.title: Enfranchisement
word.description: being granted freedom, rights, or citizenship.
word.example: immigrants becoming citizens of the country they just immigrated to.
women getting the right to vote.

word.title: entrepot
word.description: Entrepôt a center of trade that doesn't have import or export costs.

word.title: Epidemiological Transition Model
word.description: the cause of death in each stage of the Demographic Transition Model.
word.example: The main cause of death in Stage 1 of the DTM was plaques and epidemics.
The main cause of death in Stage 3 of the DTM is cardiovascular diseases and cancer.

word.title: Ethnic Cleansing
word.description: the killing of an ethnic/religious group in order to wipe out the group permanently.
word.example: usually performed by a rival ethnic group.

word.title: Ethnic Conflict
word.description: a conflict between ethnic groups.
word.example: between the Hutu and Tutsi groups in Rwanda in the 1990s.
the Balkan region in the former Yugoslavi.

word.title: Ethnic Enclave
word.description: a neighborhood with a distinct, ethnic presence.
word.example: Little Italy in New York City.

word.title: Ethnic Group
word.description: a group of people that share a common culture and heritage.

word.title: Ethnic Homeland
word.description: where a certain ethnicity originated.
word.example: Dominicans are from the Dominican Republic.

word.title: Ethnic Landscape
word.description: a landscape that reflects an ethnicity.
word.example: Chinese people are the majority of workers in Chinese restaurants.

word.title: Ethnic neighborhood
word.description: cities that are usually located in large metropolitan city where the population consists of a local culture where the people are free to practice their customs.

word.title: Ethnic Religion
word.description: a local religion that is comprised on mostly one ethnicity.

word.title: Ethnicity
word.description: the identity of a group of people who share a common ancestor and culture.

word.title: Ethnocentrism
word.description: the belief that one's ethnicity is the dominant ethnicity.

word.title: Exclave
word.description: a territory tin which its boundaries are attached to the boundaries of another territory without sharing a border with that territory.

word.title: Expansive Diffusion
word.description: the spread of ideas and innovations through different populations.

word.title: Favela
word.description: A Brazilian shanty town.

word.title: Federal
word.description: a political system in which power is shared between the national and state governments. Examples can range from the United States (where the death penalty, the access to alcohol, and the concealed weapons are limited by states) or Nigeria (where the Muslim North follow Shari'a law and the South, being Christian or animist, don't).

word.title: femaleheadedhousehold
word.description: Female-headed household a household in which the mother or oldest daughter is in charge.

word.title: festivallandscape
word.description: Festival landscape how places look during festivals and celebrations unique to different cultures.

word.title: Folk Culture
word.description: cultural traits of small communities.

word.title: Folk Food
word.description: traditional food cooked and eaten in a particular culture.
word.example: Cabbage and corned beef in Ireland.

word.title: Folk House
word.description: a type of house that reflects the culture and fashion in the area.
word.example: Stucco houses in the Southwestern United States.

word.title: Folk Song
word.description: a song that tells a story that has been in the culture and passed down from generation to generation.

word.title: Forced Migration
word.description: when people are forced out of their country and forced to live in a new country because of war, government, or natural disaster.
word.example: The Jews were pushed out of their homelands by the Roman Empire (the diaspora).
very common in Darfur, Sudan (refugees go to Rwanda and other neighboring countries).

word.title: Friction of Distance
word.description: the inhibition of distance on human activity.
word.example: A lot of people don't just hop up and drive to California.
The need of an airplane to go to Tokyo.

word.title: Folklore
word.description: traditional myths, tales, stories, songs, and beliefs passed down orally in a culture.
word.example: stories that are not written dow.

word.title: Formal Culture Region
word.description: an area where people share on or more characteristics.

word.title: Functional Culture Region
word.description: a region that is organized around a focal point or a node.

word.title: Fundamentalism
word.description: the literal interpretation of a set of basic principles.

word.title: Gateway city
word.description: a city that acts as a connection between two places, similar to a primate city.

word.title: Gender
word.description: a person's sex, male or female.

word.title: Gendered Space
word.description: an area specifically designated to a certain gender.

word.title: Gender Gap
word.description: social differences between men and women.
word.example: men usually work and bring in the money for the family.
women usually cook and stay at home with the children.

word.title: Gentrification
word.description: older, lower class homes are renovated to become more modern in order to increase property values.

word.title: Gerrymandering
word.description: Being named after Governor Elbridge Gerry, the term defines the process by which districts are drawn and redistricted to favor a group. Although gerrymandering occurs today, it is often for the reason of giving representation to the minorities. Another example of gerrymandering is during the 1950s and 1960s in the United State, a time when minorities (African Americans) were often refused to vote.

word.title: Ghetto
word.description: a lower class area occupied by a population with a uniform race, religion, or social background.

word.title: Globalization
word.description: the evolution of technology at a global scale.

word.title: Gravity Model
word.description: predicts the perfect location for a service in direct relation to the population of area and indirectly related to the distance the people have to travel to use it.
word.example: more populated cities are more likely to interact with each other than less populated cities.
cities closer together are more likely to interact than cities farther apart.

word.title: Great cities
word.description: similar to a primate city, they have influence on their country and world.

word.title: Guest Worker
word.description: a labor migrant brought in to replace the workers that died in World War II.
word.example: France received a large amount of guest workers after World War II.
Many guest workers did not return to their ho country.

word.title: Hajj
word.description: the pilgrimage made by Muslims to the holy city of Mecca.
word.example: one of the Five Pillars of Faith (Islam).
must be made at least one in a Muslim's life.

word.title: Hearth
word.description: The point of origin from where the diffusion starts.
word.example: The abundance of seafood on the coast.

word.title: Hierarchical Diffusion
word.description: ideas that get diffused first by the most connected places and cities.

word.title: High-tech corridors
word.description: a center for technology production and design.

word.title: Hinduism
word.description: third largest world religion (by followers).

word.title: Hinterland
word.description: a remote and undeveloped area.

word.title: Hydraulic civilization
word.description: a government or social structure in which control is defined by power over water.

word.title: Indigenous city
word.description: a city with a population of indigenous people.

word.title: Indo-European Language
word.description: several hundred related dialects and languages; includes most major European languages, some Middles Eastern languages, and some Asian languages.

word.title: Infanticide
word.description: the killing or murder of a child under the age of 1.
word.example: sacrificing infants was part of ancient cultures.
According to the Bible, ancient Hebrews sacrificed infants to the Gods.

word.title: Infant Mortality Rate
word.description: the number of deaths of infants under age 1 to 1000 live births.
word.example: In 2002, the IMR in the US is 7 deaths/1,000 live births.
In 2004, the IMR in Sierra Leone was 179.5, the highest in the world.

word.title: Informal sector
word.description: an economic system that isn't tracked, taxed, or monitored by the government, and is not included in the GNP.

word.title: In-filling
word.description: to fill in a space, hole, or gap.

word.title: Infrastructure
word.description: underlying structures and features of an area.

word.title: Inner city
word.description: the central area of a major city, similar to a CBD.

word.title: Innovation Adoption
word.description: how, why, and a what rate new technological innovations move throughout a society.
word.example: many people bought Xbox 360 gaming consoles when it first hit the market.
people looking to save money look for cheaper technology.

word.title: Intercontinental Migration Patterns
word.description: permanent movement from one country to another without leaving the continent.
word.example: Moving from Canada to the US.
Moving from Egypt to South Africa.

word.title: Interfaith Boundaries
word.description: boundaries between the world's major faiths.
word.example: the former Yugoslavia had many interfaith boundaries.

word.title: Internal Migration
word.description: a permanent movement to a different part of the same country.
word.example: Moving From Chengdu, China to Beijing, China.

word.title: Interregional Migration Patterns
word.description: permanent movement from one region to another.
word.example: Moving from Northern Asia to Northern Africa.
Moving from Latin America to Australia.

word.title: Intervening Opportunity
word.description: a certain feature, whether it's environmental or cultural, on a landscape that aids in migration.
word.example: a new series of job openings.

word.title: Intrafaith Boundaries
word.description: boundaries within one faith.
word.example: Protestant and Catholic in Northern Ireland.

word.title: Invasion and succession
word.description: a process where a group of immigrants move into the territory previously inhabited by other immigrants.

word.title: Islam
word.description: a monotheistic religion based on the teachings of Muhammad.

word.title: Isogloss
word.description: a geographic boundary of where a dialect is spoken.

word.title: Jainism
word.description: a religion/philosophy that was founded in ancient India.

word.title: J-Curve
word.description: when an area's population projection shows exponential growth.
word.example: an area with no carrying capacity.
there is no area on Earth with a J-curve.

word.title: Judaism
word.description: one of the first monotheistic religions.
word.example: the religion of the ancient Hebrews.

word.title: Landscapes of the Dead
word.description: a place where people are buried.

word.title: Language
word.description: a set of sounds, combination of sounds, and symbols used for communication.

word.title: Language Family
word.description: a group of languages that have a common ancestral language.

word.title: Language Group
word.description: a group of related languages.

word.title: Language Subfamily
word.description: Languages that are more related inside of a language family.

word.title: Lateral commuting
word.description: commuting between suburban areas instead of between toward the center of the city.

word.title: Life Expectancy
word.description: the number of years a person, in a certain place with certain conditions, will live.
word.example: the life expectancy is higher in wealthier countries.
most of African countries have a lower life expectancy.

word.title: Linear Pattern
word.description: The dispersal of population aligns into a line.

word.title: Lingua Franca
word.description: a common language used for trade and commerce.

word.title: Longevity Gap
word.description: the difference between the life expectancies of developed countries and developing countries.
word.example: the longevity gap between Japan and the US is 7.88 years.
the longevity gap between Canada and Germany is 1.13 years.

word.title: Maladaption
word.description: an adaption that is more harmful than it is helpful.
word.example: a species of bacteria evolving to resist antibiotics.
organisms will die off when exposed to new environmental conditions.

word.title: Maladaptive Diffusion
word.description: when an idea or innovation that is diffused to an area does not work out well.
word.example: New England style homes in the Southwestern US.

word.title: Malthus, Thomas
word.description: the first person to propose that the rate of increase of the world's population is outrunning the production of food.
word.example: assumed that the food was eaten in the country it was grown in.

word.title: Material Culture
word.description: the art, structures, dances, clothing, etc. made by the people of a culture.

word.title: Maternal Mortality rate
word.description: number of deaths of women due to pregnancy or giving birth out of 100,000 live births.
word.example: the MMR in the Central African Republic is 1,100 per 100,000 live births.
many African countries have the higher MMRs.

word.title: Medieval cities
word.description: ancient cities that used medieval practices.

word.title: Megacities
word.description: high urban areas meshed together.

word.title: Megalopolis/conurba-tion
word.description: huge megacities made of high urban areas.

word.title: Metropolitan area
word.description: a large population center consisting of a large metropolis and its adjacent zone of influence.

word.title: Migration Pattern
word.description: the different movements of people to new places.

word.title: Monotheism
word.description: the belief in only one God.

word.title: Mormonism
word.description: a branch of Christianity that is separate from Protestant denominations.
word.example: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints.
about 3 percent of Americans are Mormon.

word.title: Mortality Rate

word.title: Territoriality
word.description: Human territoriality is a term generally referring to the opinion of Robert Sack who describes human territoriality as "the attempt by an individual or group to affect, influence, or control people, phenomena, and relationships, by delimiting and asserting control over a [specific] geographic area (De Blij et. al., 2007, p.222)." There are several ways for a group to control another, including physical force or organized sets of laws. His view contrasts with that of Robert Audrey, who believes that human territoriality is similar to the general behavior of animals. By contrast, Sack believes that human territoriality is shown in many arrangements based on the settings (as the territorial strategy changes) and should not be compared to mere animal instinct. Human behavior is learned unlike animals where behavior is instinctive. Central to the idea of state is the concept of territoriality, making states such as the USA or Portugal examples of a territoriality. The concept of territoriality today is tied closely with the concept of sovereignty; In specific terms, a territoriality is defined by a country or community's strong defense and protection over its territory as a result of its sense of attachment to it.
